subject: Philosophy
title: Validity vs Soundness
description: A micro-lesson that makes Validity vs Soundness usable.

hook.text: An argument can be perfectly logical and completely wrong. That's the difference between validity and soundness.

buildup.text: A valid argument has a structure where if the premises are true, the conclusion must follow.

discovery.text: All cats can fly. Socrates is a cat. Therefore Socrates can fly. It's valid â€” the logic works â€” but it's not sound.

twist.text: Sound arguments are valid AND have true premises. That's the gold standard of reasoning.

climax.text: People often confuse logical form with truth. Good structure doesn't guarantee good content.

punchline.text: Logic can be flawless and still lead you astray.

quiz.question: What makes an argument sound?
options: It is both valid and has true premises
